action.primary: Nourishes, moistens and lubricates the Intestines

indications: Constipation after a warm febrile disease

contraindications: Contraindicated for those with loose stools.
Overdose or long-term use may result in vaginal discharge or spermatorrhea.
Over consumption can lead to impotence.
Excessive consumption can leas to nausea, vomiting and diarrhea.
Avoid use of the unprocessed herb as it is slightly toxic.

useCases: Constipation due to lack of fluids and Blood Deficiency, especially in the elderly and postpartum.
Constipation due to Heat induced Dryness in the Stomach and Intestines.
Constipation in the elderly, especially if accompanied by coughing and wheezing.
Redness, pain and ulcerations of the mouth due to Stomach Heat.
Constipation due to Body Fluid Deficiency.
Severe constipation due to general Deficiency.
Hair loss with Blood Deficiency. (apply the essential oil of Huo Ma Ren directly on the scalp and drink the He Shou Wu)

notes: Because the seeds have been processed, they cannot germinate and are therefore not considered a controlled substance.
Symptoms of overdose include nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, numbness of the extremities, irritability, chorea, and in very severe cases coma and death.
For hair loss or dry hair, use this herb as a rinse or shampoo.
For scalp ulcer, mix the powder of this herb with water and honey and apply topically.
Linum is actually the term for flax seed also used to moisturize the colon.

This herb and Sm. Pruni #{YuLiRen} Yu Li Ren are similar however Huo Ma Ren is gentler, nourishing, and treats Deficiency conditions while Yu Li Ren is stronger, promotes urination, treats edema, and is used for Excess disorders.
Dry-fried hemp Seeds Chao Ma Ren enhances its nourishing and enriching properties and reduces its slippery, facilitating properties.
It may have a heavy metal detoxicant action.
The extracted oil can be applied topically for hair loss.
